BiblioData.Title: QUANTUM COMPUTING DEVICE AND METHOD INCLUDING QUBIT ARRAYS OF ENTANGLED STATES USING NEGATIVE REFRACTIVE INDEX LENSES
BiblioData.Abstract: A quantum computing device and method employs qubit arrays of entangled states using negative refractive index lenses. A qubit includes a pair of neutral atoms separated by or disposed on opposite sides of a negative refractive index lens. The neutral atoms and negative refractive index lens are selectively energized and/or activated to cause entanglement of states of the atoms. The quantum computing device enjoys a novel architecture that is workable and scalable in terms of size and wavelength.

Claims.P: What is claimed is:
1. A qubit for use in a quantum computing system, the qubit comprising:
a pair of atoms; and
a negative index lens disposed between the pair of atoms.
2. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the negative index lens is arranged to entangle states of the pair of atoms.
3. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the negative index lens is arranged to electromagnetically link the pair of atoms.
4. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the negative index lens is arranged between the pair of atoms such that the optical path length between the pair of atoms is zero.
5. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the pair of atoms is comprised of Cesium atoms.
6. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the pair of atoms is comprised of neutral atoms.
7. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the pair of atoms is comprised of alkaline atoms.
8. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the negative index lens is comprised of a material having an index of refraction of n=-1.
9. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the negative index lens is comprised of a metamaterial.
10. The qubit of claim 1, further comprising:
a first negative index mirror disposed adjacent to a first atom of the pair of atoms; and
a second negative index mirror disposed adjacent to a second atom of the pair of atoms.
11. The qubit of claim 10, wherein the first and second negative index mirrors are comprised of materials having an index of refraction of n=-1.
12. The qubit of claim 1, wherein the negative index lens facilitates entanglement of states of the atoms.
13. The qubit of claim 1, further comprising:
a second negative index lens disposed adjacent to one of the pair of atoms; and
a third atom disposed adjacent to the second negative index lens.
14. A qubit array comprising a plurality of qubits according to claim 1.
15. The qubit array of claim 14, wherein the plurality of qubits are arranged in a two-dimensional architecture.
16. The qubit array of claim 14, wherein the plurality of qubits are arranged in a three-dimensional architecture.
17. A quantum computing system comprising:
a plurality of qubits according to claim 1;

control circuitry operatively connected to the negative index lenses, the control circuitry being operable to switch the negative index lenses between a negative index state and a positive index state; and
atomic state reading circuitry configured to determine atomic spin states of the atoms.
18. The quantum computing system of claim 17, further comprising:
an excitation source configured to excite the atoms.
19. The quantum computing system of claim 18, wherein the excitation source is configured to provide 9.2 GHz signals to excite cesium atoms.
20. A quantum computing method comprising:
disposing pairs of neutral atoms on opposite sides of negative index lenses;
selectively exciting the atoms;
selectively energizing and de-energizing the negative index lenses, the selectively energizing and de-energizing facilitating entanglement of states of the atoms; and
interrogating the atoms to determine the state of at least one of the neutral atoms.
21. The quantum computing method of claim 20, wherein interrogating includes determining spin of the atoms, the spin being indicative of state 0, state 1 or a superposition of state 0 and state 1.
22. The method of claim 20, wherein the neutral atoms are cesium atoms, and including exciting the atoms with signals having a frequency of about 9.2 GHz.
23. A quantum computing device comprising:
a plurality of neutral atoms, each pair of neutral atoms being separated by a negative index lens, wherein each pair of neutral atoms and negative index lens are arranged to define a quantum bit; and
control circuitry operatively coupled to one or more excitation sources, wherein the control circuitry and one or more excitation sources cooperate to entangle the quantum bits.
24. The quantum computing device of claim 23, wherein the quantum bits are arranged in a two-dimensional architecture.
25. The quantum computing device of claim 23 wherein the quantum bits are arranged in a three-dimensional architecture.
26. A quantum computing device comprising:
an array of elements, each element of the array comprising:
a first neutral atom;
a second neutral atom; and
a negative index lens disposed between the first and second neutral atoms;
wherein the first and second neutral atoms are arranged to define first and second basis states of a quantum bit; and
wherein the elements are arranged so as to cause entanglement of the quantum bits of the elements of the array.
